title: Why 2020 could be the pits for Rio's Oyu Tolgoi
text:
Sources suggest the forecasting process found multiple, very plausible scenarios under which the Oyu Tolgoi open pit will be cashflow negative in 2020.

Mines that become cashflow negative are often shuttered until economic conditions improve, but doing so at Oyu Tolgoi could have profound consequences for Rio's already fractious relationship with the Mongolian government, given the impact that closure would have on local employment.

That means the open pit mine is likely to continue operating even if it starts to burn cash in 2020.

“The team at OT continues to focus every day on safely optimising the performance of the open pit and progressing the underground mine in order to deliver maximum benefit for all shareholders. They are not working on plans to close the open pit,” said a Rio spokesman.

Rio and the listed subsidiary through which Oyu Tolgoi is owned, Turquoise Hill Resources, declined to say this week whether they expect the open pit to be cashflow positive in the 2020 calendar year.

Neither company was willing to disclose this week what copper and gold grades they expect to extract from the open pit in 2020, despite the start of the year being 12 weeks away.

While precise grade guidance was not available, the companies have made clear that the open pit is moving into lower grade material than it has extracted over the past year.

It is believed gold grades in the open pit will average around 0.25 grams per tonne in coming years; a far cry from the 1.4 grams per tonne extracted in recent years when the open pit was working through its "gold core".

Sources said the companies were exploring ways to "resequence" the Oyu Tolgoi mine plan to maximise cashflow from the open pit over the next two years.

Cash flow from the open pit has never been more important for Turquoise Hill, given the funding challenges the company now faces on the back of the delays to the underground project.

Many investors fear Turquoise Hill will have to conduct a dilutive equity raising within the next two years, with Turquoise Hill chief executive Ulf Quellmann saying the company has enough liquidity to last it until the end of 2020.

Mr Quellman has suggested cash flow from the open pit will complement the project finance that Turquoise Hill has on hand to sustain itself until the end of 2020, and as recently as September 9 Turquoise Hill said in an investor briefing that cash flows from the open pit were ''steady''.

''Expect to continue to generate additional cash from ongoing open-pit operations,'' said Turquoise Hill in the September briefing, without specifying whether it was referring to 2019 or 2020.

The best chance for the open pit to generate cashflow in 2020 appears to be continued appreciation of the gold price, which has soared in 2019 on signs of a global economic slowdown.

Financing

Advertisement

But the same macro economic factors have hurt the copper price, which has fallen from more than $US2.90 per pound in April to $US2.54 per pound on Friday.

Rio and Turquoise Hill have started conversations with lenders over an increase to the $US4.4 billion finance package awarded to the project by a consortium of lenders in 2015.

That consortium included ANZ, NAB and the Australian government's Export Finance and Insurance Corporation.

But that process of seeking more funding is caught between the rock that is the Mongolian government's desire for a better deal on the project, and the hard place that is the conditions lenders will require to give them comfort before they hand over more money.

Meanwhile, changes to the leadership of the underground project were confirmed this week, with underground project director Michel Charron finishing his three-year stint on the project and returning to Canada where he will take on another project role within Rio.

Charles Zimmerman, the managing director of aluminium, copper and diamonds projects, will take on greater accountability Oyu Tolgoi's underground project.

Two Australians, Andrew Duff and Chris Aitchison will also take on more responsibility, focusing on surface construction and underground mine development respectively.
description: Rio Tinto's Mongolian copper mine faces a tough year ahead, as delays to the high grade underground mine leaves the open pit exposed to sliding grades.
